defaultCourse1.title: Introduction to Informatics
defaultCourse1.explanation_recommendation: Introduction to Informatics: The course covers essential concepts of computer science including algorithms and object-oriented programming, which matches the LMU module content such as problem-algorithm-program relation, data structures, and object-oriented programming【4:0†source】.

defaultCourse2.title: Fundamentals of Programming (Exercises & Laboratory)
defaultCourse2.explanation_recommendation: Introduction to Programming (INF-EiP): This course covers programming in Java or similar languages, data structures, and recursion, aligning well with the TUM course's focus on Java programming and fundamental Informatics concepts【4:0†source】.

defaultCourse3.title: Introduction to Computer Organization and Technology - Computer Architecture
defaultCourse3.explanation_recommendation: Computer Architecture (INF-RA): The TUM course includes machine-oriented programming, microprogramming, and circuit design, which go beyond the basic introduction provided in the LMU course, resulting in an ECTS difference【4:1†source】.

defaultCourse4.title: Introduction to Software Engineering
defaultCourse4.explanation_recommendation: Software Engineering (INF-SWT): The LMU and TUM courses both cover software development processes and project management concepts, hence no deduction is recommended【4:2†source】.

defaultCourse5.title: Operating Systems and System Software
defaultCourse5.explanation_recommendation: Operating Systems (INF-BS): The course content, including concurrency, process management, and resource management, aligns well with TUM's content of operating systems, justifying full credit allocation【4:3†source】.

defaultCourse6.title: Fundamentals of Algorithms and Data Structures
defaultCourse6.explanation_recommendation: Algorithms and Data Structures (INF-AlDs): Key topics such as algorithm complexity, sorting, and data structures are covered in both TUM's and LMU's modules, thus no deduction is given【4:4†source】.

defaultCourse7.title: Fundamentals of Databases
defaultCourse7.explanation_recommendation: Database Systems I (INF-DBSI): The focus on SQL, database design, and transaction management is common between both TUM and LMU modules, justifying full credits【4:5†source】.

defaultCourse8.title: Computer Networking and IT Security
defaultCourse8.explanation_recommendation: Computer Networks and Distributed Systems (INF-RVS): Overarching networking concepts and basics of IT security taught in both courses align well, thus no deduction is necessary【4:6†source】.

defaultCourse9.title: Information Theory and Theoretical Informatics
defaultCourse9.explanation_recommendation: Formal Languages and Complexity Theory (INF-FSK): Both courses address formal languages, grammars, and complexity theory, which justifies full marks【4:7†source】.

defaultCourse10.title: Introduction to Signal Processing
defaultCourse10.explanation_recommendation: Signal Analysis: The LMU course covers signal processing concepts broadly but lacks depth in digital signal processors and image processing, leading to a slight deduction【4:8†source】.

defaultCourse11.title: Foundations of Cyber-Physical Systems
defaultCourse11.explanation_recommendation: No equivalent course: The applicant lacks an equivalent course covering essential embedded and cyber-physical systems concepts, resulting in full deduction【4:9†source】.

defaultCourse12.title: Enterprise Architecture Management and Reference Models
defaultCourse12.explanation_recommendation: No equivalent course: Missing coverage of enterprise architecture management reduces the score to zero【4:10†source】.

defaultCourse13.title: Business Process Management
defaultCourse13.explanation_recommendation: Business Process Management: Both TUM and LMU modules adequately cover the correlation between business processes and IT technology, risk management, and decision-making. Hence, no deduction is necessary【4:11†source】.

defaultCourse14.title: Discrete Structures
defaultCourse14.explanation_recommendation: Logic and Discrete Structures (INF-LDS): While both courses cover discrete mathematics and logic, TUM requires a greater integration of graph theory and combinatorics, not fully covered by LMU【4:12†source】.

defaultCourse15.title: Linear Algebra
defaultCourse15.explanation_recommendation: Linear Algebra for Computer Scientists (MA-LinAlgICS): This course partially aligns with TUM's coverage but lacks comprehensive treatment of eigenvalues and vector spaces【4:13†source】.

defaultCourse16.title: Calculus
defaultCourse16.explanation_recommendation: Calculus 1 and Calculus 2: These courses combined cover differential and integral calculus concepts required by TUM, justifying full credit allocation【4:14†source】.

defaultCourse17.title: Discrete Probability Theory
defaultCourse17.explanation_recommendation: Introduction to Probability Calculus and Inductive Statistics (STAT-EWIDS): The module's focus on probability fundamentals, stochastic processes, and inductive statistics aligns well with TUM's requirements【4:15†source】.
